entries.text: The Divine Comedy constructs moral order through a cosmological architecture grounded in Aristotelian and Thomistic metaphysics.
Dante’s Inferno maps sin as distorted love rather than merely legal transgression.
The figure of Beatrice mediates divine grace through poetic memory.
Dante’s political exile shapes the Commedia’s critique of Florentine factionalism.
In Paradiso, language approaches its limits as theology surpasses discursive representation.
The terza rima structure mirrors the Trinitarian logic embedded within the poem’s theological framework.
Dante reinterprets classical figures within a Christian teleology.
The Purgatorio stages moral transformation as gradual reorientation of desire.
Dante’s Monarchia articulates a vision of universal empire distinct from papal sovereignty.
The Commedia functions as both autobiographical journey and universal moral allegory.
